questions.text: Principal site of acidification of urine______
questions.solution:
Principal site of acidification of urine is collecting duct. Acidification occurs in both distal tubule and collecting duct, but collecting duct is more important. 

The urinary pH of 4.5 (limiting pH) is normally reached in the collecting ducts. 

In the late distal tubules and collecting ducts, the tubular epithelium secretes H+ by primary active transport. Primary active secretion of H+ occurs in type A intercalated cells of the late distal tubule and in the collecting tubules. H+ concentration can be increased as much as 900-fold in the collecting tubules.

questions.text: Most important extracellular buffer_____
questions.solution:
The most important extracellular buffer is bicarbonate. The source of bicarbonate is plasma by filteration. It is a non inducible buffer. 

Proteins: Are the most abundant intracellular buffer. 

Phosphate: minor buffer in kidney. The source is plasma by filteration. It is a noninducible buffer. 

Ammonia is a minor buffer, locally produced by tubular cells. Its production increases in metabolic acidosis. It is the only inducible buffer. 

Related Pearl: Principal buffers in the body

Extracellular Buffers Intracellular Buffers Bone Buffers
  • HCO3 (bicarbonate) -Major buffer in ECF and body
  • Plasma proteins
  • Phosphate - minor
  • NH3- minor
  • Organic phosphates [e.g., AMP, ADP, ATP, 2,3-diphosphoglycerate (DPG)]
  • Intracellular proteins
  • Hemoglobin in RBCs

It has been estimated that at least 40% of the buffering of an acute acid load takes place in the bone.

In chronic acidosis continued buffering has adverse effects on bone mineralization and can result in bone diseases such as rickets, osteomalacia, and osteopenia.

questions.text: Normal anion gap is mostly due to_____
questions.solution:
Normal anion gap is mostly due to unmeasured proteins. 

Normally in the plasma, the concentrations of anions and cations are equal to maintain electrical neutrality. Thus no real "anion gap" exists in the plasma and this is purely a diagnostic concept.

Diagnostically, when the electrolytes are measured in the blood, routinely only certain cations and anions are measured. These are Na+, Cl- and HCO3-. The anion gap is the difference between the unmeasured anions and unmeasured cations. This is estimated as :

Plasma anion gap= [Na+] - [Cl-] - [HCO3-]

The unmeasured cations include calcium, magnesium and potassium.

The unmeasured anions include albumin, phosphate, sulphate and organic anions. 

This is primarily used in measurement of different causes of metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: Normal anion gap is _________mEq / L.
questions.solution:
The normal anion gap ranges between 8 and 16 mEq/L.

The concentrations of anions and cations in plasma must be equal to maintain electrical neutrality. Therefore, there is no real “anion gap” in the plasma.

However, only certain cations and anions are routinely measured in the clinical laboratory. The cation normally measured is Na+, and the anions are usually Cl− and HCO3−.

The “anion gap” (which is only a diagnostic concept) is the difference between unmeasured anions and unmeasured cations and is estimated as

Plasma anion gap = [Na+ ] − [HCO3− ] − [Cl− ]=144−24−108 =12 mEq/L

The anion gap will increase if unmeasured anions rise or if unmeasured cations fall.

The most important unmeasured cations include calcium, magnesium and potassium and the major unmeasured anions are albumin, phosphate, sulfate and other organic anions.

Usually the unmeasured anions exceed the unmeasured cations and the anion gap ranges between 8 and 16 mEq/L.

questions.text: The major prostanoid synthesized in kidney is ________
questions.solution:
PGE2 is the major prostanoid synthesized in the kidney.

It is secreted by:

  • RMICs (Renal Medullary Interstitial Cells)
  • Macula densa
  • Cells in the collecting ducts.

Prostacyclin (PGI2) and other prostaglandins are secreted by the arterioles and glomeruli.  

Renal medullary interstitial cells (RMICs) are specialized fibroblast-like cells which are major site of cyclooxygenase 2 (COX-2) and prostaglandin synthase (PGES) expression.

questions.text: All of the following results in increased renin secretion except _____.

choices.text: Increased  amount of Na+ in DCT
Decreased amount of Na+ in PCT

questions.solution:
The increased amount of Na+ and Cl- reabsorption across macula densa (DCT) is inhibitory to renin secretion. All other factors increase renin secretion.

Renin leads to a series of events through the Renin-Angiotensin-Aldosterone pathway that finally, in simple terms, leads to salt and water retention and increases blood pressure. Therefore, it is easy to remember that all factors that cause decreased effective volume, pressure, or sodium delivery will increase the renin levels and vice versa. 

Note: Renin is secreted by the juxtaglomerular cells (granular cells) which are epitheloid cells located in the media of afferent arterioles of the glomerulus.

questions.text: Angiotensin II causes all of the following except_____
questions.solution:
Angiotensin II is one of the most potent vasoconstrictors in the body.

It constricts efferent arteriole, thereby increasing filteration fraction and glomerular filteration rate, when there is decreased renal bloodflow

Related Pearl: Actions of Angiotensin II

Facilitates the release of Norepinephrine by a direct action on postganglionic sympathetic neurons

Constricts efferent arteriole, thereby increasing filteration fraction and glomerular filteration rate, when there is decreased renal bloodflow

Direct effect on renal tubules to increase Na+ reabsorption

Acts on brain to decrease sensitivity of baroreceptor reflex, potentiating the pressor effect of AT II

Acts on brain to increase water intake and increase secretion of ADH and ACTH

questions.text: Vasopressin secretion is increased by_____
questions.solution:
Vasopressin (ADH) secretion increases in response to decreased ECF volume to bring about water retention to restore the ECF volume.

ADH exerts its antidiuretic effect by acting on the V2 receptors and involves the insertion of aquaporin 2 (AQP2) into the apical (luminal) membranes of the principal cells of the collecting ducts.

questions.text: A patient who got into an accident is brought to the casualty and is bleeding from his right leg. His blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Which of the following plays the most important role for sodium and water retention in this patient?
questions.solution:
The renin-angiotensin system plays the most important role for sodium and water retention in this patient as the patient has hypovolemia due to blood loss. (refer to figure)

The plasma concentration of renin is the rate-limiting step in the renin-angiotensin system; it is the major determinant of plasma angiotensin II concentration.

Angiotensin II stimulates the aldosterone and ADH secretion; it also constricts the blood vessels and causes thirst, which helps in maintaining blood pressure.

questions.text: Atriopeptin (ANP) acts at _____
questions.solution:
ANP acts on the collecting duct.

ANP is secreted by the atria in response to an increase in ECF volume. It decreases Na+ reabsorption in the late distal tubule and collecting ducts. It causes natriuresis.

ANP causes dilation of afferent arterioles and constriction of efferent arterioles resulting in an increased RBF(Because the dilatory effect of ANP on afferent arterioles is more than the constrictor effect on efferent arterioles, there is an overall decrease in renal vascular resistance and resulting
increase in RBF) and increased GFR.

questions.text: ANP secretion is raised by all except____
questions.solution:
It is ↑ in ECF volume and not hypovolemia that causes increased secretion of ANP.

Stimuli that increase the secretion of ANP

  • ↑atrial stretch or ventricular stretch
  • ↑isotonic saline administration
  • ↑ECF volume 

Stimuli that decrease ANP secretion

  • Rising from supine to standing position (as this decreases the central venous pressure).

questions.text: Several hormones regulate the tubular reabsorption of water and electrolytes at different sites in the nephron physiologically in a patient. Which of the following combination is correct?
questions.solution:
The combination which is correct is Aldosterone in collecting ducts.

Aldosterone acts on principal cells and intercalated cells, which are present in collecting ducts. It regulates ECF volume and Na+ content. Major stimulus for aldosterone secretion is Hyperkalemia. The functions of aldosterone are Na+ and H2O reabsorption, K+ and H+excretion. 

Option A: Angiotensin II acts on efferent arteriole. It causes vasoconstriction increasing BP. It causes constriction of efferent arteriole, increases filteration fraction, preserving GFR when RBF ↓. 

Option B: ADH acts on principal cells in collecting ducts. It primarily regulates serum osmolarity. Stimulates reabsorption of water in collecting ducts via Aquaporin-2.

Option D: ANP is released from atria and BNP is released from ventricles in response to ↑ volume, it inhibits RAAS, relaxes mesangial cells and promotes natriuresis.

questions.text: The areas associated with micturition reflex is/are ______________
questions.solution:
The micturition center is located in the pons. The paracentral lobule is also associated with micturition.

The micturition reflex is an autonomic spinal cord reflex, but it can be inhibited or facilitated by centers in the brain.

These centers include-

  • A strong facilitative and inhibitory centers in the brain stem, located mainly in the pons.
  • Centers located in the cerebral cortex that are mainly inhibitory but can become excitatory.

questions.text: ADH acts through which aquaporin channel?
questions.solution:
The antidiuretic hormone acts through aquaporin channel 2.

ADH binds to V2 receptors in the late distal tubules, collecting tubules, and collecting ducts, and stimulates the movement of an intracellular protein, called aquaporin-2 (AQP-2), to the luminal side of the cell membranes.

Clinical note: Lithium, which is often used to treat bipolar disorder, can cause acquired diabetes insipidus by decreasing the expression of the AQP2 gene.

questions.text: Ureteric peristalsis is mainly due to_____

choices.text: Pacemaker activity of smooth muscles of renal pelvis

questions.solution:
Urine flowing from the collecting ducts into the renal calyces stretches the calyces and increases their inherent pacemaker activity, which in turn initiates peristaltic contractions occur­ring 1 to 5 times per minute that spread to the renal pelvis and then downward along the length of the ureter, thereby forcing urine from the renal pelvis toward the bladder.

  • The walls of the ureters contain smooth muscle and are innervated by both sympathetic and parasympathetic nerves, as well as by an intramural plexus of neurons and nerve fibers that extends along the entire length of the ureters.
  • As with other visceral smooth muscle, peristaltic contractions in the ureter are
    • Enhanced by parasympathetic stimulation
    • Inhibited by sympathetic stimulation

questions.text: In micturition reflex, the first change to occur is_____
questions.solution:
• One of the initial events is the relaxation of the muscles of the pelvic floor, and this may cause a sufficient downward tug on the detrusor muscle to initiate its contrac­tion.
  • Micturition Reflex
  • Micturition is fundamentally a spinal reflex facili­tated and inhibited by higher brain centers and is subject to voluntary facilitation and inhibition.
  • These centers include
    • strong facilitative and inhibitory centers in the brain stem, located mainly in the pons
    • several centers located in the cerebral cortex that is mainly inhibitory but can become excitatory.
  • The micturition reflex is the basic cause of micturition, but the higher centers normally exert final control of micturition.
  • Micturition Reflex is the result of a stretch reflex initiated by sensory stretch receptors in the bladder wall, especially by the receptors in the posterior urethra when this area begins to fill with urine at the higher bladder pressures.
  • Sensory signals from the bladder stretch receptors are conducted to the sacral segments of the cord through the pelvic nerves and then reflexively back again to the bladder through the parasympathetic nerve fibers by way of these same nerves. (refer figure)
  • As the bladder continues to fill, the micturition reflexes become more frequent and cause greater contractions of the detrusor muscle.
  • Once a micturition reflex begins, it is “self-regenerative.”
  • It is a single complete cycle of
    • The progressive and rapid increase of pressure,
    • A period of sustained pressure, and
    • Return of the pressure to the basal tone of the bladder.
  • As the bladder becomes more and more filled, micturition reflexes occur more and more often and more and more powerfully.
  • Once the micturition reflex becomes powerful enough, it causes another reflex, which passes through the pudendal nerves to the external sphincter to inhibit it. If this inhibition is more potent in the brain than the voluntary constrictor signals to the external sphincter, urination will occur. If not, urination will not occur until the bladder fills still further and the micturition reflex becomes more powerful.

questions.text: How much urine in the bladder will cause the first urge to void in a patient?
questions.solution:
The first urge to void is felt at a bladder volume of about 150 mL, and a marked sense of fullness at about 400 mL.

Cystometrogram (refer figure)

A plot of intravesical pressure against the volume of fluid in the bladder is called a cystometrogram.

The curve shows

  • An initial slight rise in pressure when the first increments in the volume are produced(Ia);
  • A long, nearly flat segment as further increments are produced(Ib);
  • A sudden, sharp rise in pressure as the micturition reflex is triggered(II).
  • The flatness of segment Ib is a manifestation of the law of Laplace.
  • This law states that the pressure in a spherical viscus is equal to twice the wall tension divided by the radius.
  • P= 2T/R
  • In the case of the blad­der, the tension increases as the organ fill but so does the radius. Therefore, the pressure increase is slight until the organ is relatively full.

questions.text: In a patient, pO2 is 85mmHg, pCO2 is 50mmHg, pH is 7.2, and HCO3- is 36mmol/L. Identify the condition.

choices.text: Respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis
Respiratory alkalosis with compensatory metabolic acidosis
Respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic acidosis

questions.solution:
This patient has respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis.

pH is decreased (<7.35) so it is acidosis.

The CO2 levels are increased (>45mmHg), which is in line with the change in pH (in respiratory acidosis CO2 is expected to raise), thus the primary problem is respiratory.

The HCO3- levels are increased (>30mmol/L), which is opposite to change in pH (i.e there is acidosis and HCO3- levels are high), thus, there is compensatory metabolic alkalosis.

Thus, this is a case of respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: A patient with salicylic acid poisoning has the following arterial blood gas analysis report: pH = 7.1, pCO2 =18mmHg, HCO3-=12mmol/L. Identify the acid-base disorder here.

choices.text: Respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis
Metabolic acidosis with uncompensated respiratory alkalosis

questions.solution:
The acid-base disorder here is a mixed disorder of metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis. 

It should not be confused with metabolic acidosis with uncompensated respiratory alkalosis. This can be understood by the following calculation:

Step 1: The pH in this patient is 7.1 (pH <7.35) which indicates acidosis

Step 2: HCO3- is 12 mmol/L (Normal HCO3- - 22–30 mmol/L). In metabolic acidosis, HCO3- levels decrease.

Hence, this is a case of metabolic acidosis.

Step 3: As per Winter's formula, the expected respiratory compensation in metabolic acidosis can be calculated using,

      pCO2 =( 1.5 x [HCO3-] ) +8 ± 2

In this case, Expected pCO2 = ( 1.5 x [12] ) +8 ± 2

                                          = 26 ± 2

                                          = 24 - 28 mmHg

The pCO2 in this patient is 18 mmHg, which implies there is an overcompensation of pCO2. This overcompensation can happen only if there is an additional component of respiratory alkalosis contributing to reduced pCO2.

Hence, this patient has a mixed disorder - metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis. 

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: Which of the following patients will have metabolic alkalosis?

choices.text: A patient with chronic renal failure who is recommended dialysis
A patient who was diagnosed with hyperaldosteronism
A patient who took a whole bottle of aspirin to get rid of the headache

questions.solution:
Metabolic alkalosis is seen in patients with hyperaldosteronism.

In hyperaldosteronism: increased aldosterone levels cause increased H+ secretion by the distal tubule and increased reabsorption of HCO3- → Metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: In a patient with metabolic acidosis, which of the following changes are seen?
questions.solution:
K+ secretion into the renal tubules is decreased when the H+ secretion is increased (Intracellular Buffering of H+). Thus in metabolic acidosis, there is decreased K+ excretion.

questions.text: A normal anion gap metabolic acidosis occurs in patients with_____
questions.solution:
Diarrhoea is a cause of normal anion gap metabolic acidosis produced as a result of increased HCO3- loss in feces.

This is because a decrease in HCO3- is replaced by an increase in the concentration of Cl-.  This is a measurable anion and hence the anion gap is normal.

Extra - edge : Siggard-Anderson curve normogram is used to plot the acid-base composition of the blood
